prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

para.paratext: In practice, the Panel applies standards more detailed than those of the statute to determine if transfer will, in fact, achieve the purposes of the statute. Those factors are discussed individually in §§ 5:17 to 5:29, below. These factors include, but are not limited to:
Convenience of counsel;
Convenience of witnesses;
Minimizing of duplicative discovery;
Possibility of conflicting rulings;
Number of actions and pendency of at least one action in the proposed transferee district;
Progress of discovery at the time of proposed transfer;
Docket conditions;
Familiarity of transferee judge with issues raised;
Availability of judicial resources;
Number of actions pending in district; and
Size of litigation.[1]

Agreement by all parties that transfer is appropriate may increase the likelihood that cases will be transferred and consolidated.[2] Opposition by all parties will not, however, defeat consolidation and transfer.[3] Even if the parties agree on transfer, the Panel exercises its independent judgment to determine if the requirements of the statute are met.[4] In addition to the attitudes of the parties towards transfer, the Panel has set forth a number of other factors it will consider in determining whether transfer and consolidation for pretrial proceedings is appropriate.

The decision on the appropriateness of transfer is made in part on factors separate from those relating to selection of a transferee district (discussed in Chapter 6) and selection of a transferee judge (discussed in Chapter 7). The availability of an especially logical or appropriate transferee court or judge may, however, make the Panel more inclined to transfer litigation. For example, the fact that one judge has experience handling some of the related actions and has successfully managed them may make it easier for the Panel to conclude that transfer would meet the statutory requirement that transfer advance the just and efficient handling of the litigation.[5]

The Panel does not always address its reasons for transferring cases. In some cases the Panel has observed that the appropriateness of transfer is so apparent that the only decision to be made is one of selection of a forum.[6] In other cases the Panel has simply ordered transfer without explaining its reasons for ordering transfer.[7]

Applying the multiple factors discussed in this chapter is not formulaic or automatic. Some factors are predicticably important (number of actions, the presence of multiple class actions, etc.), but others can be important as well. To assess whether a particular docket is likely to see transfer, consider all the factors discussed in this chapter and the importance attributed to them, and attempt to determine if they point towards transfer. A useful recent article attempts to put a more quantitative face on the process, analyzing the recent decisions of the Panel and identifying a few major factors that increase or decrease the odds of transfer.[8]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
